symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare but potentially fatal disorder caused by excessive activation of macrophages and lymphocytes, leading to severe hyperinflammation. Symptoms include fever, splenomegaly, cytopenias, and hyperferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in multiple organs, particularly the lungs and lymphatic system. Symptoms may include fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary issues like wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which includes lymph nodes, spleen, thymus gland, and bone marrow. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Adult Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that presents with a characteristic set of symptoms including fever, joint pain, and a salmon-pink rash. Elevated ferritin levels are a hallmark of this condition.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, manifesting in symptoms such as fatigue, joint pain, rash, and cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also have systemic effects, including pulmonary manifestations like wheezing and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease mainly affecting the lungs. Symptoms can include coughing, wheezing, fever, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Castleman Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by non-cancerous growths that can occur in the lymph node tissue throughout the body. It can present with hyperferritinemia, lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This can lead to nausea, and in some cases, symptoms like wheezing if it leads to pulmonary involvement.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a significant increase in heart rate upon standing, along with symptoms like dizziness, fainting, and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect the connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Often associated with POTS, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. It's often associated with symptoms of POTS.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells inappropriately and excessively release chemical mediators, leading to a wide range of chronic symptoms, including hypersensitivity reactions, that can overlap with POTS symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: A broad category of diseases where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues. Some autoimmune disorders can present with POTS, mood lability, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Dysfunctions
diagnoses.description: Both hypo- and hyperthyroidism can cause symptoms such as palpitations, mood lability, and, in some cases, delayed puberty due to the crucial role of thyroid hormones in growth and metabolic regulation.

diagnoses.name: Hypogonadism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the body's sex glands produce little or no hormones. In males and females, hypogonadism may result in part from delayed puberty, and it can also affect mood.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Deficiency in certain nutrients, such as iron, vitamin D, and B vitamins, can cause symptoms like fatigue, mood lability, and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Psychiatric Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as depression and anxiety disorders can lead to symptoms like mood lability, fatigue, and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Anorexia Nervosa
diagnoses.description: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, an intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of weight. It can lead to delayed puberty, mood lability, and nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Dysgeusia and increased susceptibility to infections can be symptoms of chronic kidney disease. Pruritus is also common in patients undergoing dialysis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Diabetes can cause dysgeusia due to fluctuations in blood glucose levels and increase the risk of infections. Neuropathies associated with diabetes may also lead to symptoms like pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis B or C Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Hepatitis infections can lead to dysgeusia and increased susceptibility to infections. Chronic hepatitis can also be associated with dermatological manifestations like pruritus.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV/AIDS significantly compromises the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. Patients might also experience dysgeusia and various skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Iron-deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can cause dysgeusia and increased susceptibility to infections due to impaired immune functions. Chronic anemia might also lead to hypersomnolence due to fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Hypothyroidism can cause hypersomnolence and an increased susceptibility to infections. Dermatographic urticaria and pruritus might also occur in patients.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.rationale: Patients with autoimmune disorders may experience a wide range of symptoms, including dysgeusia, hypersomnolence, and increased susceptibility to infections due to immune dysregulation. Skin manifestations like pruritus are common.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Celiac disease can cause dermatitis herpetiformis, which involves pruritus. Dysgeusia and an increased susceptibility to infections may occur due to malabsorption and nutrient deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.rationale: In multiple sclerosis, dysgeusia and fatigue leading to hypersomnolence might occur. Immune dysregulation can also increase susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Psychological Conditions (e.g., Depression)
diagnoses.rationale: Depression can lead to hypersomnolence and alterations in taste perception or dysgeusia. It can also indirectly increase susceptibility to infections due to poor self-care.

diagnoses: Otitis Externa associated with upper respiratory infection
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) with respiratory manifestations
Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV-2 infection or COVID-19)

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.reason: Directly matches the symptom of obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Panic Disorder
diagnoses.reason: Can cause palpitations, blood pressure lability, and may be associated with obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac Arrhythmias
diagnoses.reason: Could explain the palpitations and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to palpitations, obsessive-compulsive behaviors, and affect blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
diagnoses.reason: Directly corresponds to the symptom of fibrosis, though not directly related to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Parosmia
diagnoses.reason: A specific form of dysosmia, typically caused by a disruption in the olfactory system.

diagnoses.name: Neurodegenerative Diseases
diagnoses.reason: Some, like Parkinson's disease, can feature dysosmia and potentially lead to obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Certain conditions, like hyperthyroidism, can cause palpitations, blood pressure lability, and mood symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fibrosis and potentially affecting blood pressure.

diagnoses.details: A stroke might present with symptoms like dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), aphasia (trouble with speaking or understanding language), scotoma (blind spot in vision), and less commonly, phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

MS is a chronic illness involving your central nervous system. Dysphagia and scotoma are common symptoms, and aphasia and phonophobia could also be related symptoms due to its effects on the nervous system.
Migraine sufferers could experience scotoma (as part of the 'aura'), phonophobia, and less frequently, dysphagia and aphasia.
Depending on its location, a brain tumor could cause dysphagia, aphasia, phonophobia, and visual disturbances like scotoma.
ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, can lead to dysphagia and aphasia as it progresses. While scotoma and phonophobia are less typical, neurological diseases often have varied symptoms.

This rare, chronic autoimmune disorder is characterized by muscle weakness, hence dysphagia. Scotoma might be related to ocular myasthenia gravis, and though aphasia and phonophobia are less common, various symptoms can manifest.
Sometimes called a mini-stroke, a TIA may cause temporary episodes of dysphagia, aphasia, scotoma, and possibly phonophobia.

While primarily causing hearing loss and tinnitus, if it grows large enough, it might press on other structures and cause dysphagia and, less commonly, phonophobia, aphasia, and vision problems like scotoma.
A type of brain or spinal cord tumor that can manifest with dysphagia, aphasia, and depending on its location, scotoma and phonophobia.

An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, potentially leading to dysphagia and aphasia. Scotoma and phonophobia aren't classic symptoms but can appear depending on the severity and progress of the disease.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Hepatitis B or C with associated cryoglobulinemia
Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Epilepsy (for seizures, related secondary to underlying systemic disease)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Thrombocytopenia)
Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including skin manifestations like nonscarring alopecia, neurological symptoms such as mononeuritis multiplex, joint problems including arthropathy, and renal issues, notably proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Vasculitis encompasses a group of disorders that involve inflammation of blood vessels, which can result in a wide array of symptoms. This includes mononeuritis multiplex (due to nerve vessel inflammation), arthropathy, skin changes like alopecia, and renal involvement such as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Secondary Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: While RA primarily causes arthropathy, it can also lead to systemic complications including vasculitis. The latter can be responsible for symptoms such as mononeuritis multiplex and, in more severe cases, renal involvement leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren’s Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder primarily affects the exocrine glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth, but it can also cause nonscarring alopecia, arthropathy, and in its systemic form, can involve the kidneys (proteinuria) and the nervous system (mononeuritis multiplex).

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Systemic sclerosis can manifest with skin changes including alopecia, vascular issues like mononeuritis multiplex due to vessel thickening and fibrosis, arthropathy as part of the musculoskeletal manifestations, and renal involvement including proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for muscle inflammation and weakness, dermatomyositis can show a range of symptoms. In some cases, it can include nonscarring alopecia, arthropathy as part of muscle and joint inflammation, and in more severe instances, renal involvement leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Thus, it can present with nonscarring alopecia, mononeuritis multiplex, arthropathy, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease is a vascular disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It can present with a variety of symptoms potentially including mononeuritis multiplex and, less commonly, skin manifestations like alopecia, arthropathy, and possibly proteinuria due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: In the context of nonscarring alopecia, mononeuritis multiplex (as part of peripheral neuropathy), arthropathy (HIV-associated arthropathy), and renal involvement (HIV-associated nephropathy leading to proteinuria), HIV infection should be considered.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: In its late stages, Lyme disease can cause a variety of symptoms including nonscarring alopecia, mononeuritis multiplex due to Lyme neuroborreliosis, arthropathy as part of Lyme arthritis, and less commonly, proteinuria if there is renal involvement.
